command.name: awk
command.description: Find and Replace text within file(s)

option.name: -F
option.description: Define the input field separator = regular expression fs.

option.name: -v
option.description: var=value Assign values before prog is executed, any number of -v options may be present.

option.name: -f
option.description: Set the maximum size of the input record (MaxRows)

option.name: -mr
option.description: progfile Specify a pattern to match within progfile rather then on the command line.

option.name: -mf
option.description: Set the maximum number of fields (MaxFields)

command.name: basename
command.description: Convert a full pathname to just a filename

option.name: -a
option.description: Treat every argument as a string (as if basename were invoked with just one argument)

option.name: -s
option.description: The suffix is taken as its argument, all other arguments are treated as a string.

option.name: -d
option.description: --decompress --uncompress Force decompression. bzip2, bunzip2 and bzcat are really the same program, and the decision about what actions to take is done on the basis of which name is used. This flag overrides that mechanism, and forces bzip2 to decompress.

option.name: -z
option.description: --compress The complement to -d: force compression, regardless of the invocation name.

option.name: -t
option.description: --test Check integrity of the specified file(s), but don't decompress them. This really performs a trial decompression and throws away the result.

option.name: -f
option.description: --force Force overwrite of output files. Normally, bzip2 will not over- write existing output files. Also forces bzip2 to break hard links to files, which it otherwise wouldn't do. bzip2 normally declines to decompress files which don't have the correct magic header bytes. If forced (-f), however, it will pass such files through unmodified. This is how GNU gzip behaves.

option.name: -k
option.description: --keep Keep (don't delete) input files during compression or decompression.

option.name: -s
option.description: --small Reduce memory usage, for compression, decompression and testing. Files are decompressed and tested using a modified algorithm which only requires 2.5 bytes per block byte. This means any file can be decompressed in 2300k of memory, albeit at about half the normal speed. During compression, -s selects a block size of 200k, which lim- its memory use to around the same figure, at the expense of your compression ratio. In short, if your machine is low on memory (8 megabytes or less), use -s for everything. See MEMORY MAN- AGEMENT below.

option.name: -q
option.description: --quiet Suppress non-essential warning messages. Messages pertaining to I/O errors and other critical events will not be suppressed.

option.name: -v
option.description: --verbose Verbose mode -- show the compression ratio for each file pro- cessed. Further -vs increase the verbosity level, spewing out lots of information which is primarily of interest for diagnos- tic purposes.

option.name: -L
option.description: --license -V --version Display the software version, license terms and conditions.

(or --fast) to -9 (or --best) Set the block size to 100 k, 200 k .. 900 k when compressing. Has no effect when decompressing. See MEMORY MANAGEMENT below. The --fast and --best aliases are primarily for GNU gzip compat- ibility. In particular, --fast doesnt make things signifi- cantly faster. And --best merely selects the default behaviour.
Treats all subsequent arguments as file names, even if they start with a dash. This is so you can handle files with names beginning with a dash, for example: bzip2 -- -myfilename.

option.name: -j
option.description: Display Julian days (days one-based, numbered from January 1).

option.name: -y
option.description: Display a calendar for the specified year

command.name: cat
command.description: Concatenate and print (display) the contents of file(s)

option.name: -b
option.description: Number the non-blank output lines, starting at 1

option.name: -n
option.description: Display non-printing characters (see the -v option), and display a dollar sign ($) at the end of each line.

option.name: -s
option.description: Squeeze multiple adjacent empty lines, causing the output to be single spaced.

option.name: -t
option.description: Display non-printing characters (see the -v option), and display tab characters as ^I

option.name: -u
option.description: Disable output buffering

option.name: -v
option.description: Display non-printing characters so they are visible.

option.name: -b
option.description: Number the non-blank output lines, starting at 1

option.name: -P
option.description: Use the physical directory structure instead of following symbolic links (see also the -P option to the set builtin command)

option.name: -L
option.description: Force symbolic links to be followed

option.name: -p
option.description: Use a default value for PATH that will find all the standard utilities.

option.name: -v
option.description: Print a description of command

option.name: -V
option.description: Print a verbose description of command

command.name: curl
command.description: Transfer data from or to a server

option.name: -a
option.description: /--append Append to target file when uploading (F)

option.name: -A
option.description: /--user-agent string User-Agent to send to server (H)

option.name: --anyauth
option.description: Pick any authentication method (H)

option.name: -b
option.description: /--cookie name=string/file Cookie string or file to read cookies from (H)

option.name: --basic
option.description: Use HTTP Basic Authentication (H)

option.name: -B
option.description: /--use-ascii Use ASCII/text transfer

option.name: -c
option.description: /--cookie-jar file Write cookies to this file after operation (H)

option.name: -C
option.description: /--continue-at offset Resumed transfer offset

option.name: -d
option.description: /--data data HTTP POST data (H)

option.name: --data-ascii
option.description: data HTTP POST ASCII data (H)

option.name: --data-binary
option.description: data HTTP POST binary data (H)

option.name: --negotiate
option.description: Use HTTP Negotiate Authentication (H)

option.name: --digest
option.description: Use HTTP Digest Authentication (H)

option.name: --disable-eprt
option.description: Inhibit using EPRT or LPRT (F)

option.name: --disable-epsv
option.description: Inhibit using EPSV (F)

option.name: -D
option.description: /--dump-header file Write the headers to this file

option.name: --egd-file
option.description: file EGD socket path for random data (SSL)

option.name: --tcp-nodelay
option.description: Use the TCP_NODELAY option

option.name: -e
option.description: /--referer Referer URL (H)

option.name: -E
option.description: /--cert cert[:passwd] Client certificate file and password (SSL)

option.name: --cert-type
option.description: type Certificate file type (DER/PEM/ENG) (SSL)

option.name: --key
option.description: key Private key file name (SSL/SSH)

option.name: --key-type
option.description: type Private key file type (DER/PEM/ENG) (SSL)

option.name: --pass
option.description: pass Pass phrase for the private key (SSL/SSH)

option.name: --pubkey
option.description: key Public key file name (SSH)

option.name: --engine
option.description: eng Crypto engine to use (SSL). --engine list for list

option.name: --cacert
option.description: file CA certificate to verify peer against (SSL)

option.name: --capath
option.description: directory CA directory (made using c_rehash) to verify peer against (SSL)

option.name: --ciphers
option.description: list SSL ciphers to use (SSL)

option.name: --compressed
option.description: Request compressed response (using deflate or gzip)

option.name: --connect-timeout
option.description: seconds Maximum time allowed for connection

option.name: --create-dirs
option.description: Create necessary local directory hierarchy

option.name: --crlf
option.description: Convert LF to CRLF in upload

option.name: -f
option.description: /--fail Fail silently (no output at all) on HTTP errors (H)

option.name: --ftp-account
option.description: data Account data to send when requested by server (F)

option.name: --ftp-alternative-to-user
option.description: String to replace USER [name] (F)

option.name: --ftp-create-dirs
option.description: Create the remote dirs if not present (F)

option.name: --ftp-method
option.description: [multicwd/nocwd/singlecwd] Control CWD usage (F)

option.name: --ftp-pasv
option.description: Use PASV/EPSV instead of PORT (F)

option.name: --ftp-skip-pasv-ip
option.description: Skip the IP address for PASV (F)

option.name: --ftp-ssl
option.description: Try SSL/TLS for ftp transfer (F)

option.name: --ftp-ssl-control
option.description: Require SSL/TLS for ftp login, clear for transfer (F)

option.name: --ftp-ssl-reqd
option.description: Require SSL/TLS for ftp transfer (F)

option.name: --ftp-ssl-ccc
option.description: Send CCC after authenticating (F)

option.name: --ftp-ssl-ccc-mode
option.description: [active/passive] Set CCC mode (F)

option.name: -F
option.description: /--form name=content Specify HTTP multipart POST data (H)

option.name: --form-string
option.description: name=string Specify HTTP multipart POST data (H)

option.name: -g
option.description: /--globoff Disable URL sequences and ranges using {} and []

option.name: -G
option.description: /--get Send the -d data with a HTTP GET (H)

option.name: -h
option.description: /--help This help text

option.name: -H
option.description: /--header line Custom header to pass to server (H)

option.name: --ignore-content-length
option.description: Ignore the HTTP Content-Length header

option.name: -i
option.description: /--include Include protocol headers in the output (H/F)

option.name: -I
option.description: /--head Show document info only

option.name: -j
option.description: /--junk-session-cookies Ignore session cookies read from file (H)

option.name: --interface
option.description: interface Specify network interface/address to use

option.name: --krb
option.description: level Enable kerberos with specified security level (F)

option.name: -k
option.description: /--insecure Allow connections to SSL sites without certs (H)

option.name: -K
option.description: /--config Specify which config file to read

option.name: --libcurl
option.description: file Dump libcurl equivalent code of this command line

option.name: -l
option.description: /--list-only List only names of an FTP directory (F)

option.name: --limit-rate
option.description: rate Limit transfer speed to this rate

option.name: --local-port
option.description: num[-num] Force use of these local port numbers

option.name: -L
option.description: /--location Follow Location: hints (H)

option.name: --location-trusted
option.description: Follow Location: and send authentication even to other hostnames (H)

option.name: -m
option.description: /--max-time seconds Maximum time allowed for the transfer

option.name: --max-redirs
option.description: num Maximum number of redirects allowed (H)

option.name: --max-filesize
option.description: bytes Maximum file size to download (H/F)

option.name: -M
option.description: /--manual Display the full manual

option.name: -n
option.description: /--netrc Must read .netrc for user name and password

option.name: --netrc-optional
option.description: Use either .netrc or URL; overrides -n

option.name: --ntlm
option.description: Use HTTP NTLM authentication (H)

option.name: -N
option.description: /--no-buffer Disable buffering of the output stream

option.name: --no-sessionid
option.description: Disable SSL session-ID reusing (SSL)

option.name: -o
option.description: /--output file Write output to file instead of stdout

option.name: -O
option.description: /--remote-name Write output to a file named as the remote file

option.name: -p
option.description: /--proxytunnel Operate through a HTTP proxy tunnel (using CONNECT)

option.name: --proxy-anyauth
option.description: Pick any proxy authentication method (H)

option.name: --proxy-basic
option.description: Use Basic authentication on the proxy (H)

option.name: --proxy-digest
option.description: Use Digest authentication on the proxy (H)

option.name: --proxy-ntlm
option.description: Use NTLM authentication on the proxy (H)

option.name: -P
option.description: /--ftp-port address Use PORT with address instead of PASV (F)

option.name: -q
option.description: If used as the first parameter disables .curlrc

option.name: -Q
option.description: /--quote cmd Send command(s) to server before file transfer (F/SFTP)

option.name: -r
option.description: /--range range Retrieve a byte range from a HTTP/1.1 or FTP server

option.name: --random-file
option.description: file File for reading random data from (SSL)

option.name: --raw
option.description: Pass HTTP raw, without any transfer decoding (H)

option.name: -R
option.description: /--remote-time Set the remote file's time on the local output

option.name: --retry
option.description: num Retry request num times if transient problems occur

option.name: --retry-delay
option.description: seconds When retrying, wait this many seconds between each

option.name: --retry-max-time
option.description: seconds Retry only within this period

option.name: -s
option.description: /--silent Silent mode. Don't output anything

option.name: -S
option.description: /--show-error Show error. With -s, make curl show errors when they occur

option.name: --socks4
option.description: host[:port] Use SOCKS4 proxy on given host + port

option.name: --socks5
option.description: host[:port] Use SOCKS5 proxy on given host + port

option.name: --stderr
option.description: file Where to redirect stderr. - means stdout

option.name: -t
option.description: /--telnet-option OPT=val Set telnet option

option.name: --trace
option.description: file Write a debug trace to the given file

option.name: --trace-ascii
option.description: file Like --trace but without the hex output

option.name: --trace-time
option.description: Add time stamps to trace/verbose output

option.name: -T
option.description: /--upload-file file Transfer file to remote site

option.name: --url
option.description: URL Set URL to work with

option.name: -u
option.description: /--user user[:password] Set server user and password

option.name: -U
option.description: /--proxy-user user[:password] Set proxy user and password

option.name: -v
option.description: /--verbose Make the operation more talkative

option.name: -V
option.description: /--version Show version number and quit

option.name: -w
option.description: /--write-out [format] What to output after completion

option.name: -x
option.description: /--proxy host[:port] Use HTTP proxy on given port

option.name: -X
option.description: /--request command Specify request command to use

option.name: -y
option.description: /--speed-time Time needed to trig speed-limit abort. Defaults to 30

option.name: -Y
option.description: /--speed-limit Stop transfer if below speed-limit for 'speed-time' secs

option.name: -z
option.description: /--time-cond time Transfer based on a time condition
/--http1.0 Use HTTP 1.0 (H)
/--tlsv1 Use TLSv1 (SSL)
/--sslv2 Use SSLv2 (SSL)
/--sslv3 Use SSLv3 (SSL)
/--ipv4 Resolve name to IPv4 address
/--ipv6 Resolve name to IPv6 address
/--progress-bar Display transfer progress as a progress bar

option.name: string
option.description: The text to speak on the command line. This can consist of multiple arguments, which are considered to be separated by spaces.

option.name: -f
option.description: file A file to be spoken. If file is - or neither this parameter nor a message is specified, read from standard input.

option.name: -v
option.description: voice The voice to be used: Alex, Bruce, Fred, Kathy, Vicki or Victoria Default is the voice selected in System Preferences | Speech

option.name: -o
option.description: out.aiff An AIFF file to be written.

option.name: -0 Change xargs to expect NUL (\0) characters as separators, instead of spaces and newlines. This is expected to be used in concert with the -print0 function in find.
-E
option.description: eofstr Use eofstr as a logical EOF marker.

option.name: -I
option.description: replstr Execute utility for each input line, replacing one or more occurences of replstr in up to replacements (or 5 if no -R flag is specified) arguments to utility with the entire line of input. The resulting arguments, after replacement is done, will not be allowed to grow beyond 255 bytes; this is implemented by concate- nating as much of the argument containing replstr as possible, to the constructed arguments to utility, up to 255 bytes. The 255 byte limit does not apply to arguments to utility which do not contain replstr, and furthermore, no replacement will be done on utility itself. Implies -x.

option.name: -J
option.description: replstr If this option is specified, xargs will use the data read from standard input to replace the first occurrence of replstr instead of appending that data after all other arguments. This option will not effect how many arguments will be read from input (-n), or the size of the command(s) xargs will generate (-s). The option just moves where those arguments will be placed in the command(s) that are executed. The replstr must show up as a dis- tinct argument to xargs. It will not be recognized if, for instance, it is in the middle of a quoted string. Furthermore, only the first occurrence of the replstr will be replaced. For example, the following command will copy the list of files and directories which start with an uppercase letter in the current directory to destdir: /bin/ls -1d [A-Z]* | xargs -J % cp -rp % destdir

option.name: -L
option.description: number Call utility for every number lines read. If EOF is reached and fewer lines have been read than number then utility will be called with the available lines.

option.name: -n
option.description: number Set the maximum number of arguments taken from standard input for each invocation of the utility. An invocation of utility will use less than number standard input arguments if the number of bytes accumulated (see the -s option) exceeds the specified size or there are fewer than number arguments remaining for the last invocation of utility. The current default value for number is 5000.

option.name: -p
option.description: Echo each command to be executed and ask the user whether it should be executed. An affirmative response, `y' in the POSIX locale, causes the command to be executed, any other response causes it to be skipped. No commands are executed if the process is not attached to a terminal.

option.name: -R
option.description: replacements Specify the maximum number of arguments that -I will do replace- ment in.

option.name: -s
option.description: size Set the maximum number of bytes for the command line length pro- vided to utility. The sum of the length of the utility name, the arguments passed to utility (including NULL terminators) and the current environment will be less than or equal to this number. The current default value for size is ARG_MAX - 4096.

option.name: -t
option.description: Echo the command to be executed to standard error immediately before it is executed.

option.name: -x
option.description: Force xargs to terminate immediately if a command line containing number arguments will not fit in the specified (or default) com- mand line length.
